ranked_diseases.explanation: Classic presentation with upper limb defects (absent thumb, phocomelia) and cardiac malformation (ASD). This is the most characteristic combination for Holt-Oram syndrome.
Features upper limb defects, though typically preserves thumbs. Can have cardiac defects. Less likely due to absent thumb rather than absent radius as primary feature.
Can present with severe limb reduction defects including phocomelia and cardiac defects. Usually has additional craniofacial abnormalities not mentioned here.
Can present with radial ray defects including absent thumbs and cardiac defects. However, usually has additional features like growth retardation and skin pigmentation changes.
Features cardiac defects and limb abnormalities as part of the spectrum. However, typically includes vertebral defects and other organ system involvement not mentioned here.
Duane-radial ray syndrome can present with radial ray defects and cardiac anomalies, though typically includes Duane anomaly (eye movement disorder) not mentioned in this case.
